ğŸ”ï¸ Pounamu Trading: Linear Equations

Year Level: 9-10 | Subject: Mathematics | Duration: 50 minutes

Curriculum Links: Algebra 5.1, Cultural Connections

ğŸŒ¿ Cultural Context - He Horopaki Ahurea

WhakataukÄ«: "He tangata takahi manuhiri, he mauri kino" - A person who mistreats guests has a bad life force.

Traditional pounamu (greenstone/jade) trading was central to MÄori commerce and relationships between iwi. Trade routes connected communities across Te Waipounamu (South Island) and Te Ika-a-MÄui (North Island), with complex mathematical relationships governing fair exchange.

ğŸ“š Learning Objectives

  • Solve linear equations using substitution and elimination methods
  • Apply mathematical thinking to real-world cultural contexts
  • Understand the role of mathematics in traditional MÄori commerce
  • Connect algebraic concepts to cultural values of reciprocity and fairness

ğŸ“– Lesson Structure

ğŸŒ… Opening (10 minutes) - Whakatuwera

Activity: Traditional Trading Scenarios

Setup: Students work in pairs representing different iwi

Scenario: "Your iwi has 3 large pounamu pieces and 5 small ones. Another iwi offers 2 woven mats for each large piece and 1 mat for each small piece. How many mats will you receive?"

Extension: "If mats are worth 4 kÅ«mara each, and you need 50 kÅ«mara for winter, was this a good trade?"

ğŸ“Š Main Teaching (25 minutes) - Ako Matua

Linear Equations in Trading Context

Problem 1: The Balanced Exchange

Two iwi want to make a fair trade. Iwi A has pounamu worth different values:

  • Large pieces (L) = 8 units of value each
  • Small pieces (S) = 3 units of value each

Iwi B offers: 2L + 5S = 31 units of value

Question: If they trade 3L + 2S, what value should Iwi B offer to maintain fairness?

Problem 2: Multi-iwi Trading Network

Three iwi are trading. Create equations to represent:

  • Iwi Tahu: 2x + 3y = 20 (pounamu to kai)
  • Iwi KÄi: x + 2y = 11 (pounamu to tools)

Where x = large pounamu pieces, y = small pounamu pieces

Solve: How many of each type of pounamu do they have?

ğŸ¯ Practice Activities (10 minutes) - WhakangÄtahi

Trading Post Challenge

  1. Simple Trades: 4x + 2 = 18 (How many large pounamu pieces needed?)
  2. Complex Exchanges: 3x + 5y = 35, 2x + 3y = 23 (Find x and y)
  3. Cultural Extension: Research real pounamu trading values and create your own equation

ğŸ” Assessment (5 minutes) - Aromatawai

Exit Ticket: Te Taonga Trading

Scenario: Your marae is planning a hui and needs to trade pounamu for kai.

  • Create a linear equation representing your trading situation
  • Solve your equation showing all working
  • Explain how this connects to traditional MÄori values of reciprocity

Success Criteria: Equation is realistic, solution is correct, cultural connection is meaningful

ğŸ“š Resources Needed

  • Pounamu images or samples (if available)
  • Trading scenario cards
  • Calculator (optional)
  • Map of traditional trading routes
  • Worksheet: "Pounamu Trading Problems"

ğŸ¯ Differentiation Strategies

ğŸŒŸ Extension (Gifted/Advanced):

  • Research actual historical trading ratios and create complex multi-variable equations
  • Design a trading network optimization problem
  • Connect to economics: supply and demand in traditional societies

ğŸ¤ Support (Learning Support):

  • Use concrete manipulatives (tokens representing pounamu)
  • Start with simpler one-step equations
  • Provide visual trading charts and step-by-step guides

ğŸŒ ELL Support:

  • Bilingual vocabulary cards (English/Te Reo MÄori)
  • Visual representation of all trading scenarios
  • Peer support with bilingual students

ğŸ  Homework Extension

WhÄnau Connection Activity

Interview a Family Member: Ask whÄnau about any trading, bartering, or exchange they've done. Create a linear equation to represent one of these exchanges.

Alternative: Research pounamu types (kawakawa, inanga, etc.) and create trading equations based on their relative values.

ğŸ“Š Assessment Rubric

Criteria Excellence Merit Achieved
Mathematical Accuracy All equations solved correctly with clear working Most equations correct with minor errors Basic equation solving attempted
Cultural Understanding Deep understanding of cultural context and values Good cultural connections made Basic cultural awareness shown
Problem Solving Creative approaches, multiple strategies used Clear problem-solving process evident Basic problem-solving attempted

ğŸ”— Cross-Curricular Connections

  • Social Studies: Traditional MÄori society and economics
  • Te Reo MÄori: Trading vocabulary, place names on trading routes
  • Art: Pounamu carving patterns and mathematical relationships
  • Geography: Trading route maps and distance calculations

ğŸ“ Teacher Reflection Notes

Use this space to note what worked well, what could be improved, and student responses to the cultural integration...

WhakataukÄ« for Reflection:

"NÄu te rourou, nÄku te rourou, ka ora ai te iwi"

"With your food basket and my food basket, the people will thrive."

Mathematics and culture together create richer learning experiences.
